description: From Ancient Greek ἀνάβασις (anábasis, “a going up, an ascent”), from ἀναβαίνω (anabaínō), from ᾰ̓νᾰ- (ana-, “up”) + βαίνω (baínō, “to go”).

entries.meaning: (historical) A military march up-country, especially that of Cyrus the Younger into Asia.
examples: During the French anabasis to Moscow he entered our service, made himself a prodigious favorite with the whole imperial family, and even now is only in his twenty−second year.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) The first period, or increase, of a disease; augmentation.
